document.docAuthor: Abbas, Farhat & Ke, Yanguo & Zhou, Yiwei & Ashraf, Umair & Li, Xinyue & Yu, Yunyi & Yue, Yuechong & Ahmad, Kanwar Waqas & Yu, Rangcai & Fan, Yanping
document.docTitle: Molecular cloning, characterization and expression analysis of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 involved in floral scent formation in oriental hybrid Lilium variety ‘Siberia’

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Molecular cloning, characterization and expression analysis of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 involved in floral scent formation in oriental hybrid Lilium variety ‘Siberia’

mods:name.mods:affiliation: ∗∗ & The Research Center for Ornamental Plants, College of Forestry and Landscape Architecture, South China Agricultural University, Guangzhou, 510642, China

paragraph.docTitle:
Molecular cloning, characterization and expression analysis of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 involved in floral scent formation in oriental hybrid
Lilium
variety ‘Siberia’

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: The Research Center for Ornamental Plants, College of Forestry and Landscape Architecture, South China Agricultural University, Guangzhou, 510642, China

paragraph.emphasis: College of Life Sciences, South China Agricultural University, Guangzhou, 510642, China
Department of Botany , Division of Science and Technology , University of Education , Lahore , 54770, Punjab , Pakistan
Guangdong Key Laboratory for Innovative Development and Utilization of Forest Plant Germplasm, South China Agricultural University, Guangzhou, 510642, China

subSection.paragraph: Lilium oriental hybrid
Lilium varieties
Floral scent
Terpene synthases
(E, E)-α- farnesene
D-limonene

Lilies are a commercially significant cut flower worldwide due not only to their elegant shape but also to their appealing scent. Among
Lilium
varieties,
Lilium
‘Siberia’ is a cultivar that is prominent and highly favored by consumers due to its snowy white color and strong floral scent. Here, two terpene synthase genes ( LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 ) that are responsible for floral scent production in
Lilium
‘Siberia’ were cloned and functionally characterized. Recombinant LoTPS2 specifically catalyzed the formation of ( E , E )-α- farnesene from FPP. Recombinant LoTPS4 is a multiproduct enzyme that produces D-limonene and β- myrcene as major volatile compounds and β- phellandrene, (+)-4-carene and 3-carene as minor products from GPP. Furthermore, LoTPS4 generates trans-α- bergamotene as a major product and di-epi-α- cedrene, α- cubebene and ( E )-β- farnesene as minor compounds from FPP. Subcellular localization analysis using GFP fusion constructs revealed that LoTPS2 was localized in the cytosol, whereas LoTPS4 was localized in plastids. Real-time PCR analysis showed that LoTPS2 was highly expressed in the petals and sepals of the flower, while LoTPS4 was highly expressed in the filament of the flower. Moreover, mechanical wounding of flowers revealed that LoTPS2 showed a strong response to wounding via a rapid increase in its mRNA transcript level. Our results will assist scientists in exploring the molecular mechanisms of terpene biosynthesis in this species and will provide new insight into the biotechnological modification of the floral bouquet in
Lilium
.
Abstract

The genus
Lilium
includes very popular scented bulb flower species with high economic and ornamental value.
Lilium
holds a prominent position in the world's fresh cut flower market, and its members used as potted and common landscape flowers in gardens because of their variety of colors and beautiful shapes ( Hu et al., 2013 ). Among the species in this genus,
Lilium
‘Siberia’ (Oriental hybrid) is a very popular and unique flower because of its pure snowy white color and the strong scent that it releases, and this variety is highly appreciated by consumers. Oriental hybrid lilies (
Lilium spp.
) are derived from interspecific hybridization among species of the section Archelirion , including
Lilium auratum
and
Lilium speciosum ( Yamagishi et al., 2018 )
. The majority of the fragrance produced in the
Lilium
‘Siberia’ is found in the sepals and petals, which are the key parts involved in floral scent emission ( Abbas et al., 2019 ). Moreover, the emission pattern of the floral bouquet typically matches the pollinator's activity, following a diurnal circadian rhythm ( Kong et al., 2012 ; Yokota and Yahara, 2012 ).

Floral scent formation and regulation in this spectacular breed have been ignored thus far, and the mechanism of floral scent production has not been characterized. Here, we report two terpene synthase genes involved in floral fragrance formation in
Lilium
‘Siberia’. As
Lilium species
vary in their characteristics and ornamental traits, our results will facilitate the manipulation of terpene synthase genes to achieve floral scent formation in unscented or less scented
Lilium
breeds using genetic engineering and bioinformatics tools.

The full-length open reading frames (ORF) of two terpene synthase genes designated LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 were identified from lily transcriptome unigenes (unpublished data) and amplified through PCR from the
Lilium
‘Siberia’ cDNA. LoTPS2 exhibits a putative ORF of 2265 bp and encodes a protein of 754 aa with a molecular mass of 87.7 kDa. Similarly, LoTPS4 exhibits a putative ORF of 1749 bp encoding a protein of 583 aa with a calculated molecular mass of 68.7 kDa. Plant terpene synthases are grouped into seven different subfamilies/clades, designated TPS-a through TPS-g, based on the relatedness of their amino acid sequences ( Dudareva et al., 2003 ). Phylogenetic analysis revealed that LoTPS2 belongs to the TPS-f group ( Fig. 1a ). All TPS-f clade proteins, including LoTPS2 isolated in this study, contain 221 aa corresponding to the conifer diterpene internal sequence (CDIS) domain ( Bohlmann et al., 1998 ; Nieuwenhuizen et al., 2009 ) ( Fig. 1b ). The highly conserved aspartate-rich motifs DDxxD and NSE/DTE which chelate divalent metal ions (especially Mg 2+ ) are also present in the Cterminal domains of both LoTPS2 and LoTPS4. Furthermore, LoTPS4 belongs to the TPS-b subfamily, which mainly contains angiosperm monoterpene synthases. The arginine-tryptophan rich motif RRX 8 W is found at the N-terminus of LoTPS4 but is absent in LoTPS2 ( Fig. 1c ). LoTPS4 also contains conserved RxR motifs upstream of DDxxD, which are modified to RxK motifs in LoTPS2. These motifs may take part in the initiation of the isomerization-cyclization reaction ( Martin et al., 2010 ). The accession numbers of the genes are given in Supplementary Table 1.

heading.emphasis: 2.2. Functional characterization of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4

subSection.paragraph:
To examine the enzymatic activity of LoTPS2 and LoTPS
4 in
vitro, the full-length coding regions of corresponding recombinant proteins were overexpressed in the pET30a vector using
Escherichia coli
Rosetta-gammi B ( DE 3) competent cells, and their activity was assayed with the potential substrates GPP, FPP, and GGPP. Incubation of the recombinant LoTPS2 protein with FPP resulted in the production of ( E , E )- α- farnesene, whereas no product was found when GPP and GGPP were used as substrates ( Fig. 2 ). Similarly, no product was found in the control (extracts of
E. coli
expressing the empty vector in the presence of FPP).

heading.emphasis: 2.3. Expression analysis of the LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 genes

subSection.paragraph:
Quantitative real-time PCR was performed to determine the expression of the LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 genes in various
Lilium
‘Siberia’ organ tissues (root, bulb, stem, leaf, petal, sepal, stigma, anther and filament) ( Figs. 5 and 6 ). The highest expression of LoTPS2 was observed in the petals followed by the sepals, which are the key plant parts exhibiting the highest aroma levels, indicating their major involvement in floral scent formation ( Fig. 5a ). Furthermore, LoTPS2 showed lower expression in all other organs ( Fig. 5a ). In contrast, LoTPS4 showed the highest expression level in the filament, followed by the stigma, sepals and petals of the flower, ( Fig. 5b ).

The mRNA expression levels of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 were analyzed using blooming flowers from six different fragrance types of
Lilium
varieties. The results showed that LoTPS2 was most highly expressed in the strongly scented
Lilium
‘Siberia’, followed by ‘Acapulco’ and ‘Manissa’, which are moderately scented varieties; whereas its expression was lower in ‘Longiflorum’ ( Fig. 5c ). LoTPS4 was most highly expressed in ‘Acapulco’, followed by ‘Longiflorum’ and ‘Siberia’ ( Fig. 5d ).

To investigate the relative expression of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 , the flower development process was divided into five stages, designated D1 (flower bud), D2 (slightly open), D3 (half open), D4 (fully bloom), and D5 (flower senescence) ( Fig. 6 ). LoTPS2 showed the highest expression in full-bloom flowers, whereas lower expression was observed at the D3 and D5 stages, and its expression was almost undetectable at the D1 and D2 stages ( Fig. 7a ). However, LoTPS4 showed the highest expression at the D1 stage and lower expression at the D3 and D5 stages ( Fig. 7b ). To determine the expression patterns of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4, flower development was divided into two categories: from the bud stage to full-bloom stage and from the full-bloom stage to the three days later, to examine the circadian expression pattern at 8 h intervals. During flower development, there was no expression of the LoTPS2 mRNA transcript before 48 h, and the transcript level started to increase thereafter ( Fig. 7c ). In contrast, the mRNA transcript levels of LoTPS4 were highest at the bud stage and began to decline with the development of flowers, then increased again at the full-bloom stage ( Fig. 7d ). Over the course of a day/night cycle, LoTPS2 expression followed a strong diurnal rhythm, with peak expression levels in the morning (8:00), followed by the afternoon (16:00) and deep night (24:00) ( Fig. 8a ). Similarly, the emission of ( E , E ) α- farnesene followed a diurnal circadian pattern, with the highest emission in the morning, followed by deep night and afternoon ( Fig. 8c ). Over the course of a day/night cycle, LoTPS4 showed random expression and did not follow any circadian pattern in its expression ( Fig. 8b ). D-limonene also showed a random emission pattern ( Fig. 8d ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. (a) Alignment of the amino acid sequences of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4, with AdAFS1 from
Actinidia deliciosa
( FJ265785 ) and (+)-limonene synthase (Q8L5K3) from
Citrus limon
. The protein sequences were aligned using ClustalX 2.1 and edited with GeneDoc. RRX 8 W motifs were present in LoTPS4 and (+)-limonene synthase but were missing in both LoTPS2 and AdAFS1. The conserved RRX 8 W, DDXXD , and RxR domains are underlined. (b) N-terminal sequence alignment of TPS-f clade terpene synthases. AdAFS1; CbLIS2 (
C. breweri , AAD
19840); CbLIS (
C. breweri , AAC
49395); CcLIS (
Clarkia concinna , AAD
19839). The CDIS (conifer diterpene internal sequence) is indicated by a dotted line. Dashes indicate gaps inserted for optimal alignment. (c) Phylogenetic analysis of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 from
Lilium
‘Siberia’ with amino acid sequences of other selected terpene synthases. The alignment was performed using ClustalX 2.1, and the tree was built via the neighborjoining method using the MEGA 6 program and iTOL (http://itol.embl.de/). The dot size at the branches of the tree shows bootstrap values. Accession numbers are given in a Supplementary Table 1.

Fig. 2. GC-MS analysis of products generated by LoTPS2. (a) GC-MS analysis (total ion chromatogram) of the products obtained by incubating extracts of the empty vector (control) with geranyl pyrophosphate. (b) GC-MS analysis (total ion chromatogram) of the LoTPS2 enzyme with GPP. (c) GC–MS analysis (total ion chromatogram) of the LoTPS2 enzyme with farnesyl pyrophosphate showing ( E , E )-α- farnesene as the sole product. (d) Mass spectrum of the peak. (e) Mass spectrum of ( E , E )-α- farnesene in the NIST08 library.

heading.emphasis: 2.4. The expression of LoTPSs and emission of volatiles was induced by mechanical wounding

subSection.paragraph:
Previous research has indicated that terpene synthases (especially sesqui-TPSs and mono-TPSs) are involved in floral defense and airborne signaling under certain conditions. The results revealed that LoTPS2 showed a quick response to mechanical wounding in
Lilium
‘Siberia’, indicating its possible involvement in a defense reaction, signaling or attraction of pollinators. The mRNA transcript level of LoTPS2 started to increase after 1/5 h after wounding and peaked after 1 h (~2.6 fold–higher expression compared to the control) ( Fig. 9a ). At 1 h after wounding, the transcript levels began to decrease, then rapidly increased after 6 h (~2.4 fold-higher expressions) and declined thereafter. Similarly, the emission of ( E , E )-α- farnesene was undetectable before 2 h after wounding; however, its emission started increase after 4 h, and maximum emission was observed at 6 h, followed by 8 h, compared to the control ( Fig. 9b ). A similar response is observed in
Artemisia annua
and
Lotus japonicas
when they are subjected to wounding, resulting in higher transcript levels of TPSs ( Lu et al., 2002 ; Arimura et al., 2004 ). On the other hand, LoTPS4 did not show any response to wounding injury.

The analysis of putative targeting sequences with different algorithms did not provide consistent predictions about the subcellular localization of the LoTPS2 protein, suggesting the presence of either a cytosolic/nuclear localization or chloroplast targeting sequence. To experimentally determine the subcellular localization of the LoTPS2 protein, transient expression of a green fluorescent protein (GFP) fusion protein was performed in
Arabidopsis
protoplasts. The full-length fragment beginning with the start codon of the LoTPS2 gene was introduced in frame into the vector p35 S-EGFP-1 and the construct transferred to
Arabidopsis
protoplasts, which were subsequently examined for transient GFP expression through confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM). The results showed that the fusion of LoTPS2 with GFP localized to the cytosol ( Fig. 10 ). In contrast, LoTPS4 was predicted to possess an N-terminal targeting peptide that is present in chloroplast monoterpene synthases but absent in cytosolic sesquiterpene synthases. To verify the actual subcellular localization of LoTPS4, constructs including the N-terminal 80 aa and the full-length peptide of LoTPS4 were generated as described above. The results showed that both the Nterminal and full-length peptides of LoTPS4 were located in plastids. The GFP constructs evidently supported the localization of LoTPS2 to the cytosol ( Fig. 10e–h ) and LoTPS4 to the plastids ( Fig. 10 i-p). Furthermore, HcTPS7 from
Hedychium coronarium
was observed as a positive control ( Yue et al., 2014 ).

According to phylogenetic analysis, LoTPS2 was grouped in the TPSf clade/subfamily of terpene synthases, which includes
Clarkia breweri
mono-TPSs ( Dudareva et al., 1996 ), Actinidia deliciosa farnesene synthase 1 ( Nieuwenhuizen et al., 2009 ),
Vitis vinifera TPS ( Martin et al., 2010 )
,
Malus domestica TPS
30 ( Nieuwenhuizen et al., 2013 ) and
Arabidopsis thaliana TPS
04 ( Herde et al., 2008 ). Interestingly, although LoTPS2 is not a di-TPS, it contains a conserved conifer diterpene internal sequence (CDIS) domain near the N-terminal region, which is a unique property of TPS-f clade members and di-TPSs ( Fig. 1 ). It is assumed that this structural constituent existed in a general di-TPS ancestor and was lost during the evolution of mono-TPSs and sesqui-TPSs ( Bohlmann et al., 1998 ; Nieuwenhuizen et al., 2009 ). In addition, DDxxD and NSE/DTE motifs present at the C-terminus are responsible for the synchronization of divalent metal ions and substrate binding ( Degenhardt et al., 2009 ). In contrast, LoTPS4 belongs to the TPS-b clade, which includes the majority of mono-TPSs, mostly consisting of angiosperm mono-TPSs ( Dudareva et al., 2003 ). The TPS-b subfamily frequently includes RRX 8 W motifs, for the cyclization of mono-TPSs and plastid domains located in the N-terminal region of TPSs ( Bohlmann et al., 1998 ). The phylogenetic tree indicates that LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 might have exhibited diverse functions in floral scent formation during evolution.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 3. (a) GC-MS analysis of products produced from assays with extracts of the empty vector and GPP. (b) Analysis (total ion chromatogram) of the product of the LoTPS4 enzyme generated from GPP (c) Total ion chromatogram of the D-limonene authentic standard. (d) Mass spectrum of the Peak 3 (e) Mass spectrum of Dlimonene in the floral scent of
Lilium
‘Siberia’ (f) Mass spectrum of the D-limonene authentic standard (g, h, I and j) Mass spectra of Peak 1, Peak 2, Peak 4 and Peak 5. β- Phellandrene (Peak 1), β- myrcene (Peak 2), D-limonene (Peak 3), 3-Carene (Peak 4) and (+)-4-Carene (Peak 5).

Fig. 4. Product analysis of LoTPS4 produced from GGPP and FPP. (a) GC-MS analysis (ion chromatogram) of the LoTPS4 enzyme product from GGPP. (b) GC-MS analysis (ion chromatogram) of products obtained from assays with LoTPS4 and FPP. (c, d, e, f) Mass spectra of Peak 1, Peak 2, Peak 3 and Peak 4. Di-epi-α- cedrene (Peak 1), α- cubebene (Peak 2): trans-α- bergamotene (Peak 3) and ( E )-β- farnesene (Peak 4).

paragraph.emphasis:
3.2. Expression of patterns of LoTPS2 and LoTPS 4 in Lilium
‘
Siberia
’

subSection.paragraph:
Analysis of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 expression levels in different organs and tissues of
Lilium
‘Siberia’ indicated that LoTPS2 was expressed in all plant parts, showing the highest levels in the petals followed by the sepals of the flower, which are the major sources of floral scent emissions ( Fig. 5 ). In contrast to LoTPS2 , LoTPS4 was most highly expressed in the filament of the flower, followed by the sepals and anthers of the flower. Our findings are consistent with a previous study showing that sepals and petals are the main sources of flower scent emissions ( Fan et al., 2007 ; Hu et al., 2013 ; Abbas et al., 2019 ). In
Lilium
‘Siberia’, LoTPS1 and LoTPS3 are highly expressed in the sepals and petals of the flower ( Abbas et al., 2019 ). In kiwifruit, two terpene synthases are responsible for the production of sesquiterpenes and are released mainly from the floral components of the plant ( Nieuwenhuizen et al., 2009 ). Similarly, in
Syringa oblata
and
S. oblata var. alba , SoLIM
is responsible for the production of limonene and is specifically expressed in the floral components of the plant ( Yan et al., 2018 ). During flower developmental stages, the mRNA accumulation of LoTPS2 was very low at the flower bud stage and peaked at the full-bloom stage, then decreased at the senescence stage ( Fig. 6 ). Thus, the expression of LoTPS2 is developmentally-regulated and correlates with the floral scent emission pattern. In
Lilium
‘Siberia’, the emission of monoterpenes and the expression of LoTPS1 and LoTPS3 gradually increase with the development of flowers ( Abbas et al., 2019 ). LoTPS4 showed the highest expression beginning in the bud stage, while the D-limonene began to be released at the full-bloom stage. A similar pattern is observed in
S. oblata var. alba
, in which SoLIM shows its highest expression at the bud stage ( Yan et al., 2018 ).

In
Lilium
‘Siberia’, floral scent emissions exhibit rhythmic day/night rhythmic patterns. Under natural light conditions (12 h light/12 h dark), the expression pattern of LoTPS2 exhibits a diurnal circadian rhythm, with peak expression observed in the morning, followed by the afternoon and deep night ( Fig. 8a ). Likewise, the emission pattern of α-farnesene follows a diurnal circadian rhythm, peaking in the morning ( Fig. 8b ). However, LoTPS4 expression did not follow any circadian pattern ( Fig. 7b ). Nevertheless, the emission of D-limonene showed weak circadian oscillation ( Fig. 8d ). Our results are consistent with previous research showing that floral scent emissions in
Lilium
‘Siberia’ exhibit diurnal circadian oscillations ( Zhang et al., 2013 , 2017 ). The expression of TPS genes and the emission of monoterpenes are positively correlated with each other ( Abbas et al., 2019 ). In
Phalaenopsis bellina
and
P. violacea
flowers, the emission of monoterpenes occurs during the daytime and their emission is mainly affected by the circadian clock ( Chuang et al., 2017 ). Most plants release the maximum amount of terpenoids in the daytime, regulated by an internal circadian clock or light ( Dudareva et al., 2003 ). The emission of volatile organic compounds is highly regulated, and most of species are entertained to emit their scent compounds at a particular time during the day ( Pichersky and Gershenzon, 2002 ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 5. Relative gene expression analysis of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 in floraland vegetative tissues of
Lilium
‘Siberia’ (a) relative expression levels of LoTPS2 in different tissues of
Lilium
‘Siberia’ (b) Relative expression levels of LoTPS4 in different tissues of
Lilium
‘Siberia’ analyzed by qRT-PCR. (c, d) Relative expression levels of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 in full-bloom flowers of different
Lilium species.
GAPDH was used as an internal control. The highest expression level was set as 1 (100%). Lon: Longiflorum; Bru: Brunello; Sib: Siberia ; Aca: Acapulco; Sor: Sorbonne; Man: Manissa. Data are presented as the mean ± SEM (n = 4).

subSection.paragraph:
Moreover, the LoTPS2 gene responds to wounding injury of a flower ( Fig. 9 ). Terpenoids play roles in signaling to other plants, defense against herbivores, insect repellences, and pollinator attraction and are the primary contributors to the chemical arsenal of plants ( Ali et al., 2012 ; Abbas et al., 2017 ). In
Populus trichocarpa , PtTPS
2 is responsible for the biosynthesis of ( E , E )-α- farnesene and increases transcript abundance upon herbivory attack ( Danner et al., 2011 ). Furthermore, the accumulation of HcFPPS mRNA in
H. coronarium
is induced by herbivory and mechanical injury ( Lan et al., 2013 ). Similarly, an increase in the emission of farnesene and bergamotene is observed in maize upon herbivory attack ( Köllner et al., 2008 ).

heading.emphasis: 3.3. Functional characterization of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4

subSection.paragraph:
In contrast to LoTPS2, LoTPS4 is a multiproduct enzyme that utilizes both GPP and FPP to produce monoterpenes and sesquiterpenes, respectively. LoTPS4 produces multiple monoterpenes (predominantly Dlimonene) from GPP and multiple sesquiterpenes (predominantly transα- bergamotene) from FPP. Numerous terpene synthases have been found that are capable of producing several terpenes from a single substrate ( Davis and Croteau, 2000 ; Landmann et al., 2007 ; Nieuwenhuizen et al., 2013 ; Yue et al., 2014 ), and the profile of terpenes mostly includes one or two compounds that dominate as main products with others as minor products. Similarly, LaLIMS from
Lavandula angustifolia
flowers produces a blend of numerous monoterpenes, with limonene as a major product and terpinolene, pinene, camphene, α- phellandrene, and β- myrcene as minor products generated from GPP ( Landmann et al., 2007 ). Similarly, LaBERS from
Lavandula angustifolia
produces trans-α- bergamotene as a major product, while ( E )-nerolidol, ( Z )-α- bisabolene, ( E )-β- farnesene and β- phellandrene are produced in smaller amounts from FPP. Cl (+) LIMS1 and Cl (+) LIMS2 from
Citrus limon
generates almost exclusively limonene, with a lesser amount of α- pinene and β- myrcene from GPP ( Lücker et al., 2002 ). Limonene has many biochemical effects and is also recognized as an anticancer agent. Limonene has also been considered to be a safer food additive as compared to synthetic ( Sun, 2007 ; Jia et al., 2013 ). To our knowledge, this is the first report of limonene synthase from
Lilium
‘Siberia’. Limonene possesses anti-carcinogenic properties and is widely used in the cosmetic and beverage industries ( Crowell and Gould, 1994 ; Brokl et al., 2013 ). The introduction of limonene synthase genes from
C. breweri
into petunia resulted in linalool synthase production which repels aphids ( Lücker et al., 2001 ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 6. (a) A labeled diagram of a fullbloom
Lilium
‘Siberia’ flower. (b) Pictorial view of
Lilium
‘Siberia’ flowers at different flower developmental stages.

Fig. 7. Relative expression analysis of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 during different flower development performed by quantitative real-time PCR. (a, b) Transcript levels of the LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 genes during flower development. (c, d) Relative expression analysis of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 at different flower developmental stages. Flower development was divided into 5 different stages: D1 (bud stage), D2 (little open), D3 (half open), D4 (full-bloom), D5 (senescence). GAPDH was used as an internal control. The root was set as 1. Data are presented as the mean ± SEM (n = 3).

subSection.paragraph:
In plants, the biosynthesis of monoterpenes normally occurs in plastids, where GPP is synthesized, while the formation of sesquiterpenes occurs in the cytosol, where FPP is generated ( Degenhardt et al., 2009 ; Gutensohn et al., 2013 ). A subcellular localization study confirmed LoTPS2 to be localized to the cytosol, where it specifically catalyzes the transformation of FPP into ( E , E )-α- farnesene, whereas LoTPS4 localizes to plastids. Metabolic engineering of terpene synthase genes in tobacco,
Arabidopsis , Fragaria species
and potato showed the existence of a small pool of GPP in the cytosol and FPP in the plastids ( Aharoni et al., 2003 ; Wu et al., 2006 ; Schilmiller et al., 2009 ). Likewise, TPS02 from
Arabidopsis
is able to utilize both GPP and FPP to produce monoterpenes and sesquiterpenes, respectively ( Huang et al., 2010 ). However, the presence of different amounts of substrate (high FPP/low GPP in the cytosol and vice versa in plastids) would permit dual activity of the enzyme to produce monoterpenes and sesquiterpenes in both locations. LoTPS4 probably acts mainly as a monoterpene synthase, as sesquiterpene products produced by LoTPS4 were detected in the floral volatile profile of
Lilium
‘Siberia’ at some stages under the experimental conditions of the present study.

In conclusion, we functionally characterized two terpene synthases that are responsible for the production of floral scent in
Lilium
‘Siberia’ and localize to different compartments. LoTPS2 is a sesqui-TPS responsible for the biosynthesis of ( E , E )-α- farnesene exclusively from FPP, whereas LoTPS4 is a multiproduct terpene synthase that synthesizes both monoterpenes and sesquiterpenes from GPP and FPP, respectively. Our findings lay a molecular foundation for understanding the molecular mechanism underlying floral scent production.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 8. Relative expression analysis of LoTPS genes and the emission of ( E , E )-α- farnesene and D-limonene from
Lilium
‘Siberia’ at different time intervals. (a, b) Expression pattern of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 for 3 days postanthesis. (c) Emission pattern of ( E , E )-α- farnesene from
Lilium
‘Siberia’ (d) Emission pattern of D-limonene from
Lilium
‘Siberia’ flowers over 3 days after full-bloom. The plants were kept under a 12 h light, 12 h dark photoperiod. GAPDH was used as an internal control. Each point is the average of 3 replicates.

subSection.paragraph:
The lily cultivars (‘Siberia’, ‘Sorborne’ ‘Brunello’, ‘Acapulco’, ‘Longiflorum’, and ‘Manissa’) were grown in South China Agricultural University under natural light conditions.
Lilium
‘Siberia’ plants were bought from a wholesale
Lilium
‘Siberia’ cut flower market followed by immediate transfer to sterile water in a growth chamber (12-h light/12- h dark cycle). For the subcellular localization experiments,
Arabidopsis thaliana
ecotype Col-0 plants were grown in a growth chamber at 22 ̊ C under a 12-h light/12-h dark cycle.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 9. qRT-PCR expression analysis of LoTPS2 and the emission of ( E , E )-α- farnesene contents from
Lilium
‘Siberia’ flowers subjected to mechanical wounding. (a) Changes in transcript levels of LoTPS2 in
Lilium
‘Siberia’ flowers at different time intervals after treatment. GAPDH was used as an internal control (b) GC-MS analysis of ( E , E )-α- farnesene contents released from
Lilium
‘Siberia’ flowers after wounding treatment. The samples were collected 1/2, 1, 2, 4, 6 and 8 h after wounding treatment. Each point is the average for 3–5 independent experiments. Lowercase letters on bars indicate statistically significant differences at P <0.01. Vertical bars show the standard error values. ND: nondetectable.

Fig. 10. Subcellular localization of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4. Confocal laser scanning microscopy of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 was performed by using EGFP fusion proteins in
Arabidopsis
protoplasts. The full-length coding region and the N-terminal 80 amino acids of the coding region of LoTPSs were fused to the GFP reporter gene in the p35 S vector to generate the p35 S-LoTPSs/GFP construct. The red column shows chlorophyll autofluorescence; the green column shows GFP fluorescence; the merged columns show combined GFP fluorescence and chlorophyll autofluorescence; and the BF columns represent bright field images. The names of the constructs are given on the left. HcTPS7 from
H. coronarium
was used as a marker. Scale bars: 5 μm. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

subSection.paragraph:
Two terpene synthase genes ( LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 ) were selected from
Lilium
‘Siberia’ transcriptome data (data unpublished), based on the gene ontology (GO) annotation. Total RNA was extracted from full-bloom flowers using a plant RNA mini kit (Magen) according to the manufacturer's instructions. The M-MuLV First cDNA Synthesis Kit (TaKaRa, Japan ), was used to synthesize first-strand cDNA according to the manufacturer's protocol. High-fidelity KOD-Plus DNA polymerase (TOYOBO) was used to clone the full-length genes according to the manufacturer's suggestions. The polymerase chain reaction ( PCR ) conditions were as follows: 94 ̊ C for 2 min, followed by 40 cycles of 98 ̊ C for 10 s and 68 ̊ C for 1.5 min. The PCR product was extracted and purified from an agarose gel and purified using an Agarose Gel DNA Purification Kit (TaKaRa, Japan ) according to the manufacturer's instructions, followed by ligation into the TaKaRa pMD19-T vector (TaKaRa, Japan ) and sequencing.

heading.emphasis: 4.4. Heterologous expression of LoTPSs in Escherichia coli and partial purification

document.paragraph:
For functional characterization of the LoTPSs, their sequences were cloned into the expression vector pET-30a (Novagen) using the Kpn 1 site as a start codon and Not 1 downstream of the stop codon as described previously ( Abbas et al., 2019 ). The ORFs were amplified by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) using high-fidelity KOD-Plus DNA polymerase (TOYOBA). Sequence analysis showed that the sequences were correctly introduced without error. Thereafter, the expression constructs were transformed into
E. coli
Rosetta-gammi B (DE3) competent cells. A verified single colony of transformants was incubated overnight at 37 ̊C at 120 rpm in Luria-Bertani (LB) medium supplemented with kanamycin (100 μg/ml) and chloramphenicol (34 μg/ml). The next day, the culture was diluted 1:50 with LB medium supplemented with antibiotics and under the same conditions as described above until an OD 600 of 0.4–0.8 was observed. The culture was incubated at 16 ̊C and 120 rpm after the induction of expression by adding isopropyl-β- D-thiogalactopyranoside (IPTG). The next day, the cells were harvested via centrifugation ( 5000 g , 10 min) followed by sonication as described previously ( Abbas et al., 2019 ). Thereafter, the lysates were subjected to purification by loading onto Ni–NTA HisPur Resins (Thermo Fisher) according to the manufacturer's instructions. All steps were carried out at 4 ̊C. The protein concentration was determined through the Bradford method using BSA as a standard.

subSection.paragraph:
Standard assays were performed in a total volume of 1 ml containing assay buffer (20 mM MgCl 2 , 30 mM HEPES, pH 7.5, 5 mM DTT), 20 μM substrate (GPP, GGPP, and FPP) and the recombinant LoTPS proteins. Polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS, with 50/30 μm divinylbenzene/ Carboxen) fiber (Supelco) for solid-phase microextraction was used to collect volatiles. The mixture was incubated at 30 ̊ C for 30 min followed by insertion of PDMS fiber into a gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) system for volatile analysis. An Agilent 7890 A gas chromatography system coupled with an Agilent 5975 C mass spectrometry detector was used for GC-MS analyses as described previously ( Abbas et al., 2019 ). The products were recognized by comparing their mass spectra with the NIST08 mass spectrum library and known or authentic standards volatile compounds of
Lilium
‘Siberia’.

heading.emphasis: 4.6. Subcellular localization of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 proteins

subSection.paragraph:
Different computer-based prediction servers (TargetP [http://www. cbs.dtu.dk/services/TargetP/], ChloroP [http://www.cbs.dtu.dk/ services/ChloroP/], WoLF PSORT [http://wolfpsort.seq.cbrc.jp/], SignalP [http://www.cbs.dtu.dk/services/SignalP/], Predotar [http:// urgi.versailles.inra.fr/predotar], iPSORT [http://ipsort.hgc.jp/predict. cgi], and PredisSi [http://www.predisi.de/index.html] were used to analyze the N-terminal sequences of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4. The 240-bp fragments encoding the 80 aa N-terminal peptides of LoTPS2 and LoTPS4 were amplified via PCR with an Spe 1 site at the 5′ end and an Nco1 site at the 3′ end of both inserts and these sequences were cloned into the p35 S-EGFP-1 vector ( Wang et al., 2002 ). Similarly, the full-length sequence of LoTPS2 was cloned into the p35 S-EGFP-1 vector selecting a Sal 1 site at the 5′ end and a Sac1 site at the 3′ end, while for LoTPS4, a Sac1 site was selected at the 5′ end and Nco1 site at the 3′ end. The accuracy of the insertion of the sequences into the vector was confirmed. The isolation and transformation of protoplasts from
Arabidopsis
were carried out as described by Sheen ( Yoo et al., 2007 ). Protoplasts were observed 16 h after transformation through Leica TCS SP2 AOBS Spectral Confocal Scanner and further processed by Adobe Photoshop. The primers used in the study are listed in Supplementary Table 2.

Total RNA was extracted from different tissues (root, bulb, stem, leaf, sepal, petal, stigma, anther, and filament) and flower developmental stages named (D1, D2, D3, D4, and D5) ( Fig. 6a and b ) using HiPure plant RNA mini kit (Magen) following the manufacturer's instructions. One microgram of RNA was reverse transcribed by using the PrimeScript™ RT reagent Kit with genomic DNA Eraser (Takara) following the manufacturer's suggestions. Using Primer Premier 5.0 software, the reference genes were cloned from
Lilium
‘Siberia’ based on showing high conservation in plants. GAPDH was used as a reference gene for each sample. The sequence-specific primers for real-time PCR are listed in Supplementary Table 2. Gene-specific primers were used to amplify a 250 bp fragment in the 3′ end region of the sequence. Quantitative RT-PCR was performed in an ABI 7500 Fast Real-Time PCR System (Applied Biosystems, USA ) using iTaq™ Universal SYBRṜ Green Supermix (BIO-RAD, USA ) according to the manufacturer's protocol. qRT-PCR was performed in a total volume of 20 μl containing 10 μl iTaq™ Universal SYBRṜ Green Supermix, 2 μl cDNA obtained from different plant tissues, forward and reverse primer with following conditions; 95 ̊ C for 1 min followed by 40 cycles of 95 ̊ C for 15 s, 55 ̊ C for 30 s, 72 ̊ C for 30sec. The specificity of each primer pair was confirmed via melting and a standard curve. All experiments were repeated with 3 technical replicates, and the relative expression levels of target genes were calculated via the 2 −ΔΔCt method ( Livak and Schmittgen, 2001 ) and analyzed statistically.

heading.emphasis: 4.8. Headspace analysis of floral volatiles and mechanical wounding

subSection.paragraph:
The development of flowers was divided into two stages: first from the bud stage to the full-bloom stage and from after the full-bloom stage to the senescence stage to check the circadian pattern of emissions. GC-MS analysis was performed at 8 h intervals from the bud stage to senescence, followed by freezing in liquid nitrogen and storage at −80 ̊ C for further analysis. A flower was placed in a 2000 ml beaker to which 2 μl decanoic acid was added as an internal standard, and the beaker was covered with an aluminum sheet for 30 min to trap the volatiles. Thereafter, PDMS fiber (Supelco) was inserted into the beaker for 30 min to adsorb the volatiles, followed by insertion into a GC-MS system (Agilent) with Agilent 7890 A GC and Agilent 5975 C MSD, equipped with an Agilent HP-5MS capillary column ( 30 m × 0.25 mm ) and helium gas was used as a carrier at a constant flow of 1 ml min −1 as described previously ( Abbas et al., 2019 ). The list of volatile compounds and their retention time emitted from
Lilium
‘Siberia’ flowers are given in Supplementary Table 3. By comparing the retention time and mass spectra with the authentic standards, the volatiles were identified.

The wounding of flowers was performed with sterilized blades to a depth of 2–3 mm , followed by the collection of volatiles at 0, 1/2, 1, 2, 4, 6 and 8 h after treatment. At each point, a control was also performed, followed by freezing in liquid nitrogen and storage at −80 ̊ C for further experiments.
The authors declare that they have no competing interests.

This work is supported by National Key Research and Development Program of China (Grant No. 2018YFD1000407) to Yanping Fan, National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 31770738) to Yanping Fan and People's livelihood science and technology projects of Guangzhou (Grant no. 201903010054) to Yanping Fan and National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 31870690) to Rangcai Yu.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2020.112294.

GPP Geranyl pyrophosphate
FPP Farnesyl pyrophosphate GC–MS Gas chromatography–mass spectrometry
IPP Isopentenyl pyrophosphate
DMAPP Dimethylallyl pyrophosphate
MEP Methylerythritol phosphate
MVA Mevalonic acid
GGPP Geranylgeranyl diphosphate
ORF Open reading frame
qRT-PCR Quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction GFP Green fluorescence protein
Mono-TPSs Monoterpene synthases
TPSs Terpene synthases
GO Gene ontology
LB Luria–Bertani
IPTG Isopropyl-β- d-thiogalactopyranoside
PMSF Phenylmethanesulfonyl fuoride
BSA Bovine serum albumin
PDMS Polydimethylsiloxane
LSCM Laser scanning confocal microscopy
RT-PCR Reverse transcription PCR
DA Decanoic acid

FA, YF, and RY conceived and designed the experiments. FA and YK performed the experiments, analyzed the data: FA, YK, ZY, UA, XL, YY and KWA contributed reagents/materials/analysis tools: FA and RY drafted the manuscript. YF and RY revised the manuscript. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.
